commit_message:
Fix failover of az-specific loadbalancers

There is a bug exists in CalculateAmphoraDelta class
If there is no such a key as constants.MANAGEMENT_NETWORK
in availability_zone dictionary, method get will return None
It means that management_nets list will become [None], not
CONF.controller_worker.amp_boot_network_list as it supposes to be
It breaks the following failover flow

Story: 2008669
Task: 41957
Change-Id: I435c40a5493828bce24c2850182f0ddc8e5bdd1f
(cherry picked from commit 81134bdfec79c8019c26e7846d31a2b2952965a0)
(cherry picked from commit 77a87a7f335464180933cd1859cd34998d7f2e75)

commit_message:
Fix failover of az-specific loadbalancers

There is a bug exists in CalculateAmphoraDelta class
If there is no such a key as constants.MANAGEMENT_NETWORK
in availability_zone dictionary, method get will return None
It means that management_nets list will become [None], not
CONF.controller_worker.amp_boot_network_list as it supposes to be
It breaks the following failover flow

Story: 2008669
Task: 41957
Change-Id: I435c40a5493828bce24c2850182f0ddc8e5bdd1f
(cherry picked from commit 81134bdfec79c8019c26e7846d31a2b2952965a0)

[{'created': '2021-11-08 07:22:52.000000000', 'message': "Re-read the partition table with partx -a

Re-read the partition table with 'partx -a', rather than 'partx -u'.

This should fix an timing issue where the bootloader installation
fails to mount the EFI partition from a whole disk image since it
is not yet aware of the new partitions (observed with both, the
iscsi and the direct deploy interface).

Change-Id: If5da3075e813ae01df3decf8f0647aba111b0515
"}]
commit_message:
Re-read the partition table with partx -a

Re-read the partition table with 'partx -a', rather than 'partx -u'.

This should fix an timing issue where the bootloader installation
fails to mount the EFI partition from a whole disk image since it
is not yet aware of the new partitions (observed with both, the
iscsi and the direct deploy interface).

Change-Id: If5da3075e813ae01df3decf8f0647aba111b0515

[{'created': '2021-10-14 17:19:38.000000000', 'message': "Fix typo in message policy deprecations

The similarity in the variable names for get and get_all slipped through
when we implemented project personas support for messages:

  https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/cinder/+/806631

As a result, oslo.policy thought the policy name was changing, but it's
not. This commit updates the policy deprecations to use the right
deprecation variables.

Change-Id: I2a83ab07ccec80b910c614a5f5743d642491e592
(cherry picked from commit 651c936f22ac2a124ef1cfd486a5d3e6b1113e80)
"}]
commit_message:
Fix typo in message policy deprecations

The similarity in the variable names for get and get_all slipped through
when we implemented project personas support for messages:

  https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/cinder/+/806631

As a result, oslo.policy thought the policy name was changing, but it's
not. This commit updates the policy deprecations to use the right
deprecation variables.

Change-Id: I2a83ab07ccec80b910c614a5f5743d642491e592
(cherry picked from commit 651c936f22ac2a124ef1cfd486a5d3e6b1113e80)

revisions:
[{'created': '2021-11-03 11:57:51.000000000', 'message': "compute: Return details of attached volumes

The API behind the 'server add volume' command returns details of the
created volume attachment, however, we were dropping these results
rather than displaying them to the user. Correct this.

Change-Id: I3f7e121220d29422ccf4e6940de2f28bb8496c83
Signed-off-by: Stephen Finucane <sfinucan@redhat.com>
"}]
commit_message:
compute: Return details of attached volumes

The API behind the 'server add volume' command returns details of the
created volume attachment, however, we were dropping these results
rather than displaying them to the user. Correct this.

Change-Id: I3f7e121220d29422ccf4e6940de2f28bb8496c83
Signed-off-by: Stephen Finucane <sfinucan@redhat.com>

commit_message:
Tests: Fix compatibility with ddt 1.2.x

stable/victoria lists that ddt 1.2.1 is supported,
but this decoration does not work with that version
of ddt.

Remove the TestNameFormat parameter for these tests.

(stable-branch only fix)
Closes-Bug: #1948934
Change-Id: Ic91a978303f11617bf29c88bf82235998947552a

commit_message:
Update undercloud install for EL8

I think we can probably use RHEL / CentOS 8
defaults now for these docs. I added a note
to refer to the EL7 way for older installs.

Change-Id: Ifee55aef3761eecfc9683d6cfa96cc4832076736

(1 comment)

While I do agree this will more than probably change our life for the better, I'd have a concern regarding the validations.

Indeed, validations are currently shipped as ansible-playbooks, and the whole framework is about ansible, with specific python libs for the callbacks (output+logs) and so on.

If TripleO drops ansible, we'll have an issue with the VF itself, and we'd better ensure the involved folks are on the same boat, and either that directord/task-core can be used by validations, or that validations have their own way, without adding too many dependencies, especially seeing the non-packaging of Ansible is coming to our face (one of the reasons of this new spec).

@Gael, @DavidP, @Jiri, @Mathieu: care to have a look and provide some inputs on the actual impact on the VF? I'm pretty sure about the potentials answers, btw ;).

Cheers,

C."}, {'account_id': 14985, 'date': '2021-07-26 13:39:29.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

> Patch Set 2:
> 
> (1 comment)
> 
> While I do agree this will more than probably change our life for the better, I'd have a concern regarding the validations.
> 
> Indeed, validations are currently shipped as ansible-playbooks, and the whole framework is about ansible, with specific python libs for the callbacks (output+logs) and so on.
> 

Validations could continue to consume ansible however they will need to handle that requirement and how it gets invoked going forward.  It's likely that if the validation framework wants to continue to be ansible, they will need to adopt execution environments in the future.

> If TripleO drops ansible, we'll have an issue with the VF itself, and we'd better ensure the involved folks are on the same boat, and either that directord/task-core can be used by validations, or that validations have their own way, without adding too many dependencies, especially seeing the non-packaging of Ansible is coming to our face (one of the reasons of this new spec).
> 

We don't necessarily plan on dropping ansible as a whole, however we won't be consuming it for the internal deployment framework. We expect ansible will continue to be installed for the forseeable future, however there should not be any expectation that it will be the core execution method for deployments & upgrades.

> @Gael, @DavidP, @Jiri, @Mathieu: care to have a look and provide some inputs on the actual impact on the VF? I'm pretty sure about the potentials answers, btw ;).
> 
> Cheers,
> 
> C."}, {'account_id': 7353, 'date': '2021-07-26 14:44:36.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

Question: will there be something to replace the data provided by /etc/puppet/hieradata (also on the OC nodes)?

Thing is: those data are currently used by some services, such as validations and, maybe later, by a new way of running the container healthchecks (it's still under discussion, and using hieradata to get some of the needed info is a possibility).

If we get rid of puppet, this will probably mean the end of hiera as well... Guess it would be good to get a replacement.

I didn't see anything about that in the spec."}, {'account_id': 4264, 'date': '2021-07-27 10:53:07.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Code-Review-1

(1 comment)

While this looks like a good direction, could you please clarify how this is going to impact current users of tht, and how these templates are going to change (if so)?
We know there are a good amount of somewhat self-made templates out there, which are used with various OpenStack releases.'}, {'account_id': 32926, 'date': '2021-07-27 12:09:22.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: Code-Review-1

> 
> Indeed, validations are currently shipped as ansible-playbooks, and the whole framework is about ansible, with specific python libs for the callbacks (output+logs) and so on.
> 
> If TripleO drops ansible, we'll have an issue with the VF itself, and we'd better ensure the involved folks are on the same boat, and either that directord/task-core can be used by validations, or that validations have their own way, without adding too many dependencies, especially seeing the non-packaging of Ansible is coming to our face (one of the reasons of this new spec).
> 
> @Gael, @DavidP, @Jiri, @Mathieu: care to have a look and provide some inputs on the actual impact on the VF? I'm pretty sure about the potentials answers, btw ;).
> 
> Cheers,
>

Some validations will definitely need adjustment.
And that is in case if the information is available."}, {'account_id': 32926, 'date': '2021-07-27 13:14:02.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

(10 comments)

I have a local checkout with some changes, I'll hold it back to ensure we're capturing everyone's feedback without needing to reassert reviews."}, {'account_id': 7353, 'date': '2021-07-27 19:48:01.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

> Patch Set 2: Code-Review-1
> 
> (1 comment)
> 
> While this looks like a good direction, could you please clarify how this is going to impact current users of tht, and how these templates are going to change (if so)?
> We know there are a good amount of somewhat self-made templates out there, which are used with various OpenStack releases.

The goal is to not disrupt consumer templates and not take away capabilities within our existing THT infrastructure. We're looking to replace base execution and orchestration using Task-Core and Directord. To be clear, Task-Core is pluggable making it possible to target both Ansible and Directord, which should allow us to change how we run without major disruption, affording us time to port execution code (roles and playbooks) as necessary. We're in no way wanting to change the TripleO user interface, nor are we wanting to modify the user-experience when it comes to customization. This initiative has come about so that we can better support operations across large scale environments. The hope is to create a paradigm shift in how deployments, updates, and upgrades are run; making things faster, more transparent, and easier to develop for TripleO."}, {'account_id': 7353, 'date': '2021-07-27 19:54:11.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

> Patch Set 2: Code-Review-1
> 
> Question: will there be something to replace the data provided by /etc/puppet/hieradata (also on the OC nodes)?
> 
> Thing is: those data are currently used by some services, such as validations and, maybe later, by a new way of running the container healthchecks (it's still under discussion, and using hieradata to get some of the needed info is a possibility).
> 
> If we get rid of puppet, this will probably mean the end of hiera as well... Guess it would be good to get a replacement.
> 
> I didn't see anything about that in the spec.

There's nothing in this spec on a heiradata replacement. That said, we very well may replace puppet modules as we move toward these new tools so I would urge the VF to use Heiradata with caution."}, {'account_id': 8833, 'date': '2021-07-28 02:57:37.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

> > 
> > Thing is: those data are currently used by some services, such as validations and, maybe later, by a new way of running the container healthchecks (it's still under discussion, and using hieradata to get some of the needed info is a possibility).
> > 
> > If we get rid of puppet, this will probably mean the end of hiera as well... Guess it would be good to get a replacement.
> > 
> > I didn't see anything about that in the spec.
> 
> There's nothing in this spec on a heiradata replacement. That said, we very well may replace puppet modules as we move toward these new tools so I would urge the VF to use Heiradata with caution.

Understood; thanks.  At present I believe VF _itself_ does not use hiera at all, but various existing _validations_ do, so we'll need to look into how to rework this in a hieraless future.

Action for us is to go through and vet all our hiera-touching code."}, {'account_id': 7353, 'date': '2021-07-28 12:13:42.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

(1 comment)

TLDR: stick with ansible as long as you can, use k8s for the new architecture.

The proposal here has some nice ideas to explore. If I were going to pursue them I think I would start from scratch though. The reason being primarily that there is so much changing under the hood I think building it, testing it, and then using it may end up causing confusion to someone who is used to what has become TripleO.

When I think of recent TripleO changes it has included widespread adoption of Ansible. In fact Ansible is used in more places than just the deployment workflow and upgrades now. Its used directly by Tripleoclient that recent work would need to be moved back to python? And with the recent networkv2 stuff we no longer use Heat templates directly to drive that but Ansible templates. Perhaps an oversimplification but it seems we've recently remove abstractions like network templates... and just use raw Ansible instead. But now all of a sudden we can't use Ansible anymore? This doesn't jive. In my mind the installer uses Ansible so heavily I'm not trying to drop it is worth the effort. Replacing it isn't going to be a good user experience so why even try.

So perhaps there is more to be said about staying the course with Ansible and continuing the simplification efforts. We still have years of Ansible support ahead even with new versions right?

If we do want to explore the architecture being proposed here I would very much propose it as a clean room/net new framework first. Is there a prototype yet? How long to implement something that would just bootstrap a baremetal host, configure networking, and install keystone? Then estimate the rest of the services from there. I think its going to add up quick.

Lastly I would also ask how a k8s based installer would compare with what we are proposing here. And might the efforts be better invested there?"}, {'account_id': 8833, 'date': '2021-08-10 03:41:18.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 360, 'date': '2021-08-10 13:02:30.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5:

One more idea about the role of Heat in this architecture. If you were to start from scratch today and try to implement what you are proposing here would you still incorporate this component? Understood there is in the spec now thinking towards upgrades, but like I said above I think so much is changing it might be worth considering this design in a clean room scenario first.'}, {'account_id': 14985, 'date': '2021-08-10 13:20:43.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 7353, 'date': '2021-08-10 14:07:44.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 5:

> Patch Set 5:
> 
> One more idea about the role of Heat in this architecture. If you were to start from scratch today and try to implement what you are proposing here would you still incorporate this component? Understood there is in the spec now thinking towards upgrades, but like I said above I think so much is changing it might be worth considering this design in a clean room scenario first.

If I was starting from scratch, I would not incorporate any of the Heat components. In our task-core and directord repositories we have example orchestrations which can standup a multi-node minimal keystone environment in around 5 minutes, on pre-deployed hosts; this is not something possible in the OpenStack ecosystem. Heat as an interface, is and has always been, a tough user-experience and I would not want to re-implement that if starting from a clean room scenario.

While we're proposing a lot of Ansible changes in the stack, not much else is changing in terms of user experience or expectations. Structurally we want to keep upgrades and updates so we're not introducing an inflection point. As mentioned in previous comments, more than half of the Ansible used in TripleO is shell, command, or set_fact. When we look at the tasks knowing that we're really just running a lot of BASH, speeding up our execution by more than 10000% will have a significant time to delivery impact, all without actually having to change much. While it's true that the runner will be different, and the execution model will be impacted, the tasks themselves will remain mostly unchanged."}, {'account_id': 7353, 'date': '2021-08-10 14:40:57.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 5:

> Patch Set 5:
> 
> (1 comment)
> 
> TLDR: stick with ansible as long as you can, use k8s for the new architecture.

This was not the TL;DR.

> The proposal here has some nice ideas to explore. If I were going to pursue them I think I would start from scratch though. The reason being primarily that there is so much changing under the hood I think building it, testing it, and then using it may end up causing confusion to someone who is used to what has become TripleO.

I disagree that anyone who's used TripleO will be confused by the current proposal. We're looking to replace the Ansible components within TripleO not the entirety of the stack. The user experience, for better or worse, will remain the same; just the time to delivery will be faster and more reliable. Operators that have their own Ansible playbooks will 100% be able to still run them; in fact task-core has an interface to do just that.

> When I think of recent TripleO changes it has included widespread adoption of Ansible. In fact Ansible is used in more places than just the deployment workflow and upgrades now. Its used directly by Tripleoclient that recent work would need to be moved back to python? And with the recent networkv2 stuff we no longer use Heat templates directly to drive that but Ansible templates. Perhaps an oversimplification but it seems we've recently remove abstractions like network templates... and just use raw Ansible instead. But now all of a sudden we can't use Ansible anymore? This doesn't jive. In my mind the installer uses Ansible so heavily I'm not trying to drop it is worth the effort. Replacing it isn't going to be a good user experience so why even try.

You are correct in that we use Ansible in more places today than before, but an analysis of our tasks show most of the tasks are BASH. Sure there are places where we template things, and we have custom modules, but that doesn't take away from the fact that we're really just running shell commands for the majority of our workloads. Within the proposed replacement of Ansible we have the conceived the ability to easily port Ansible modules into the new tool-chain, this is especially true for TripleO where our modules don't make use of Ansible internals; we have an example of that in the repo. Additionally, in the case of teamplating, the use of Jinja2 is not relegated to an Ansible capability and is something already supported in the new system. Moving to a new tool-chain will create work for teams as they port their roles to orchestrations; however, do so should not be a terrible user experience and in-fact should net a better overall experience for their customers when complete.

> So perhaps there is more to be said about staying the course with Ansible and continuing the simplification efforts. We still have years of Ansible support ahead even with new versions right?

No, we have less than one year left with Ansible unless we move to execution environments.

> If we do want to explore the architecture being proposed here I would very much propose it as a clean room/net new framework first. Is there a prototype yet? How long to implement something that would just bootstrap a baremetal host, configure networking, and install keystone? Then estimate the rest of the services from there. I think its going to add up quick.

We actually have an example within task-core that deploys keystone, it is quit minimal but proves the point in that we can be up and running with the new tools in around 5 minutes when using pre-deployed hosts. Rounding out our OpenStack capabilities in an entirely new framework would take time, but I don't know if it would take as long as some may think. That said, we're really not wanting to abandon TripleO given we know operators are leveraging it and we don't want to abandon them. 

> Lastly I would also ask how a k8s based installer would compare with what we are proposing here. And might the efforts be better invested there?

I don't think K8S is relevant here given the first principles all of this is being built off of [0]. If we were going that route I would probably purse a collaboration with OSH given they've already got a functional, native K8S deployment environment; even if it is lacking in some places. I can't see how shoving TripleO into K8S would provide any value given all of the moving parts TripleO has. If we were starting from a clean-room and not adopting any of the existing stack as a starting point, I think a K8S installer would be something worth investigating; however, I believe TripleO blackboxed into a K8S installer would effectively create the worst overall user experience especially when it came time to troubleshoot or operate the environment long term.

[0] https://specs.openstack.org/openstack/tripleo-specs/specs/policy/first-principles.html"}, {'account_id': 9592, 'date': '2021-08-10 16:56:29.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5: Code-Review+2

FWIW.. +2'}, {'account_id': 7144, 'date': '2021-08-11 11:19:48.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 5:

(1 comment)

Alternative:

Instead of trying to combine what we have today with task-core/taskflow/directord, what if we looked at an approach where we cleaned room with the new tools (task*/directord), but had an interface for backwards compatibility?

Example, if I'm a new installer, and I don't care about any of the old interfaces, I use the new tools, or at least that is what tripleoclient does by default.

If  I'm upgrading, I could also choose to migrate any of my implementation or custom integrations to the new framework.

If I'm upgrading and want to maintain the old interfaces because of either my custom integrations, custom hieradata, or 3rd party integrations that don't yet support the new framework, then I can toggle a flag (or automatic detection) to enable the old interfaces to generate the Heat stack, and the associated set of task-core tasks or ansible playbooks.

We would need some sort of check(s) in place to make sure that old and new weren't both being used for the same service.

I think we could also re-use some of existing interfaces such as roles_data and network_data as we wouldn't need Heat to process those if we just wanted to use the new tools. We could have some python that went from roles_data -> task-core."}, {'account_id': 6926, 'date': '2021-08-11 11:38:37.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5: Code-Review-2

> Patch Set 5:
> 
> > Patch Set 5:
> > 
> > (1 comment)
> > 
> > TLDR: stick with ansible as long as you can, use k8s for the new architecture.
> 
> This was not the TL;DR.

Sorry, that was the TLDR for for my reply. (not your spec)

> 
> > The proposal here has some nice ideas to explore. If I were going to pursue them I think I would start from scratch though. The reason being primarily that there is so much changing under the hood I think building it, testing it, and then using it may end up causing confusion to someone who is used to what has become TripleO.
> 
> I disagree that anyone who's used TripleO will be confused by the current proposal. We're looking to replace the Ansible components within TripleO not the entirety of the stack. The user experience, for better or worse, will remain the same; just the time to delivery will be faster and more reliable. Operators that have their own Ansible playbooks will 100% be able to still run them; in fact task-core has an interface to do just that.
> 
> > When I think of recent TripleO changes it has included widespread adoption of Ansible. In fact Ansible is used in more places than just the deployment workflow and upgrades now. Its used directly by Tripleoclient that recent work would need to be moved back to python? And with the recent networkv2 stuff we no longer use Heat templates directly to drive that but Ansible templates. Perhaps an oversimplification but it seems we've recently remove abstractions like network templates... and just use raw Ansible instead. But now all of a sudden we can't use Ansible anymore? This doesn't jive. In my mind the installer uses Ansible so heavily I'm not trying to drop it is worth the effort. Replacing it isn't going to be a good user experience so why even try.
> 
> You are correct in that we use Ansible in more places today than before, but an analysis of our tasks show most of the tasks are BASH. Sure there are places where we template things, and we have custom modules, but that doesn't take away from the fact that we're really just running shell commands for the majority of our workloads. Within the proposed replacement of Ansible we have the conceived the ability to easily port Ansible modules into the new tool-chain, this is especially true for TripleO where our modules don't make use of Ansible internals; we have an example of that in the repo. Additionally, in the case of teamplating, the use of Jinja2 is not relegated to an Ansible capability and is something already supported in the new system. Moving to a new tool-chain will create work for teams as they port their roles to orchestrations; however, do so should not be a terrible user experience and in-fact should net a better overall experience for their customers when complete.

I count 4 unique ways Ansible is now used within Tripleo. For deployment, for upgrades, for tripleoclient, and now even for network configuration templates. Perhaps there are more? Adopting it at all of these levels has taken years. I do agree some of them could be abstracted from the user but many of those interfaces are directly exposed to the user now so breaking changes are almost certainly going to be involved here in terms of user interfaces. Perhaps this is fine, but I do think its worth calling out specifically in this spec. There is a cost here. Perhaps it can't be avoided.

> 
> > So perhaps there is more to be said about staying the course with Ansible and continuing the simplification efforts. We still have years of Ansible support ahead even with new versions right?
> 
> No, we have less than one year left with Ansible unless we move to execution environments.
> 
> > If we do want to explore the architecture being proposed here I would very much propose it as a clean room/net new framework first. Is there a prototype yet? How long to implement something that would just bootstrap a baremetal host, configure networking, and install keystone? Then estimate the rest of the services from there. I think its going to add up quick.
> 
> We actually have an example within task-core that deploys keystone, it is quit minimal but proves the point in that we can be up and running with the new tools in around 5 minutes when using pre-deployed hosts. Rounding out our OpenStack capabilities in an entirely new framework would take time, but I don't know if it would take as long as some may think. That said, we're really not wanting to abandon TripleO given we know operators are leveraging it and we don't want to abandon them. 

I didn't say you had to abandon old users. What I was getting at was that the architecture here has aspects that are so net-new that a prototype might suite better to work the kinks out, scale test, and trail blaze before you commit to it. If you being forced to change/rethinking some of the exposed Ansible interfaces anyway might go even further. Then once you have that put in a plan for how existing users upgrade to the new tooling. You are already selling the merits of the new architecture in this spec as a means to encourage users to upgrade. The upgrade itself is still possible, just the interfaces and tooling are changing.

If the timeframe and scope was different I might suggest something different (all of this within a year to avoid moving to Ansible execution environments?)

> 
> > Lastly I would also ask how a k8s based installer would compare with what we are proposing here. And might the efforts be better invested there?
> 
> I don't think K8S is relevant here given the first principles all of this is being built off of [0]. If we were going that route I would probably purse a collaboration with OSH given they've already got a functional, native K8S deployment environment; even if it is lacking in some places. I can't see how shoving TripleO into K8S would provide any value given all of the moving parts TripleO has. If we were starting from a clean-room and not adopting any of the existing stack as a starting point, I think a K8S installer would be something worth investigating; however, I believe TripleO blackboxed into a K8S installer would effectively create the worst overall user experience especially when it came time to troubleshoot or operate the environment long term.

I was in fact talking about the what if we consider the clean room case. (Nothing I said here was to imply that we should "shove" or "blackbox" TripleO onto k8s as you assert). What is being proposed here is a significant effort though. And as such we might consider where things might end up years down the road and benefits of a world with more modern deployment tooling. There have been many efforts in this territory in the past years some internal to Red Hat, and others in the OpenStack community that might be worthy of consideration. And like above there could still be a sort of upgrade path for existing users into these modern architectures. Might have to wiggle with a few of the first principles a bit but I think the general sentiment could be achieved. 


> 
> [0] https://specs.openstack.org/openstack/tripleo-specs/specs/policy/first-principles.html'}, {'account_id': 360, 'date': '2021-08-11 17:11:54.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5:

> 
> I'd be very careful of a clean room approach. We do not have a clean room. We have existing deployments, existing partner integrations, etc.

Clean room doesn't have to mean we entirely abandon existing deployments. Rather more just an observation that perhaps so much is changing under the hood with what is being proposed in this spec that we might be better served by kicking off the effort in a clean room first.'}, {'account_id': 14985, 'date': '2021-08-11 18:06:33.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5:

> 
> I count 4 unique ways Ansible is now used within Tripleo. For deployment, for upgrades, for tripleoclient, and now even for network configuration templates. Perhaps there are more? Adopting it at all of these levels has taken years. I do agree some of them could be abstracted from the user but many of those interfaces are directly exposed to the user now so breaking changes are almost certainly going to be involved here in terms of user interfaces. Perhaps this is fine, but I do think its worth calling out specifically in this spec. There is a cost here. Perhaps it can't be avoided.

None of these ways should be directly invoked by the user and and the actual interface is tripleoclient.  The fact that we've allowed end users to go around tripleoclient (e.g. config-download) is a repeated failing on our part because we haven't provided the correct tooling for the needed use cases.  With the exception of perhaps the new network config via ansible (but this is a metalsmith/provisioning aspect), every other one is a tripleoclient cli action which we would want to migrate the execution under the covers so it is not changing what the end user does.


> I was in fact talking about the what if we consider the clean room case. (Nothing I said here was to imply that we should "shove" or "blackbox" TripleO onto k8s as you assert). What is being proposed here is a significant effort though. And as such we might consider where things might end up years down the road and benefits of a world with more modern deployment tooling. There have been many efforts in this territory in the past years some internal to Red Hat, and others in the OpenStack community that might be worthy of consideration. And like above there could still be a sort of upgrade path for existing users into these modern architectures. Might have to wiggle with a few of the first principles a bit but I think the general sentiment could be achieved. 

I question why this continues to be considered a significant effort. It's probably less effort than the initial containerization or config-download (which didn't have a spec btw).  In fact this spec has vastly more detail and scale information than the initial container-tripleo-overcloud[0] spec so I continue to have trouble understanding the continued push back on this effort.  This effort is to take the existing functionality of the overall deployment framework and confine the functionality we need to projects or code bases designed for the required action rather than leveraging projects that don't focus solely on these functions (heat/ansible).  Our goal is for this to not be invasive and people continue to claim it will be.  

Our existing tooling is insufficient and this is our proposal to address the upcoming issues due to tooling changes and scale related problems.  If you think there's another set of tools we should use or have thoughts about that, please provide that information rather than requesting us to go do that investigation. We did investigations and initial PoCs to address pain points that we currently hit (e.g. limited task ordering, excessive time to execute work, poor execution status) with the tooling we use today for the required actions we do as part of the deployment of containerized services on baremetal hosts.  We feel this is a limited solution without breaking the world or scraping tripleo in it's entirety.  If you think there's another solution, feel free to file a different spec as an alternative or provide levels of details similar to what is being referenced here. 

[0] https://specs.openstack.org/openstack/tripleo-specs/specs/ocata/containerize-tripleo-overcloud.html'}, {'account_id': 7144, 'date': '2021-08-11 19:03:58.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 7353, 'date': '2021-08-11 19:49:02.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5:

> If the timeframe and scope was different I might suggest something different (all of this within a year to avoid moving to Ansible execution environments?)

No, this was all conceived and presented at the last PTG as a potential means to improve our time to delivery. The Ansible execution environment transition only became an issue when we discovered that moving to them would require us to add a minimum of 45 minutes to our typical deployment time when running test environments (best case); actual production clouds could see an even more significant impact.'}, {'account_id': 7144, 'date': '2021-08-11 19:52:22.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5:

(1 comment)

> I question why this continues to be considered a significant effort. It's probably less effort than the initial containerization or config-download (which didn't have a spec btw).  In fact this spec has vastly more detail and scale information than the initial container-tripleo-overcloud[0] spec so I continue to have trouble understanding the continued push back on this effort.  This effort is to take the existing functionality of the overall deployment framework and confine the functionality we need to projects or code bases designed for the required action rather than leveraging projects that don't focus solely on these functions (heat/ansible).  Our goal is for this to not be invasive and people continue to claim it will be.  

I don't view it as push back. I'm not saying no, and I agree we should try what is proposed in the spec. But I think we need to prove it out more. I asked for more of a real world example, pseudo code, poc, prototype, whatever. The "clean room" was an alternative to use the new tools (directord/task-core), but ignore Heat/ansible. Then maybe explore backwards compatibility as an option.

You assert that we didn't do enough of planning and concensus building in the past and you raised some examples (containerization, config-download), and you characterize that as a mistake. If that's the case, then we should approach these decisions *differently* this time around. Not claim that since we did it one way in the past, we should do it that way again.

Yes, I agree with the POV that this spec is being held to a higher bar than in the past. That's a good thing if we consider that tooling choices in the past may have been incorrect.'}, {'account_id': 7353, 'date': '2021-08-11 19:57:25.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 14985, 'date': '2021-08-11 20:14:56.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5:

(1 comment)

> I don't view it as push back. I'm not saying no, and I agree we should try what is proposed in the spec. But I think we need to prove it out more. I asked for more of a real world example, pseudo code, poc, prototype, whatever. The "clean room" was an alternative to use the new tools (directord/task-core), but ignore Heat/ansible. Then maybe explore backwards compatibility as an option.

I think our goal was to include backwards compatibility from the start which is why this feels like it's push back. The goal is to not do dramatic changes to the overall deployment so the talk of k8s, etc seem to be not relevant to the proposed spec.

> 
> You assert that we didn't do enough of planning and concensus building in the past and you raised some examples (containerization, config-download), and you characterize that as a mistake. If that's the case, then we should approach these decisions *differently* this time around. Not claim that since we did it one way in the past, we should do it that way again.

I would argue we aren't doing the same thing again which is why there are details around scale testing and being able to reproduce complex setups to test architectures beyond what we have today. We've considered these and have the data or examples to show how they work. 
 
> Yes, I agree with the POV that this spec is being held to a higher bar than in the past. That's a good thing if we consider that tooling choices in the past may have been incorrect.

I'm just not certain that the suggestions or asks are necessarily aligned with being able to correctly determine if this is a good path or not.  It seems like we need to better describe scope and reasoning to highlight that the goal is not to write a complete solution from scratch (we're replacing functionality), we must have backwards compatibility (so a completely different approach is not appropriate), and we want to be able to test the pieces separately for various scales (distinct projects).'}, {'account_id': 360, 'date': '2021-08-11 20:31:32.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5:

> Patch Set 5:
> 
> > 
> > I count 4 unique ways Ansible is now used within Tripleo. For deployment, for upgrades, for tripleoclient, and now even for network configuration templates. Perhaps there are more? Adopting it at all of these levels has taken years. I do agree some of them could be abstracted from the user but many of those interfaces are directly exposed to the user now so breaking changes are almost certainly going to be involved here in terms of user interfaces. Perhaps this is fine, but I do think its worth calling out specifically in this spec. There is a cost here. Perhaps it can't be avoided.
> 
> None of these ways should be directly invoked by the user and and the actual interface is tripleoclient.  The fact that we've allowed end users to go around tripleoclient (e.g. config-download) is a repeated failing on our part because we haven't provided the correct tooling for the needed use cases.  With the exception of perhaps the new network config via ansible (but this is a metalsmith/provisioning aspect), every other one is a tripleoclient cli action which we would want to migrate the execution under the covers so it is not changing what the end user does.

But config-download is now a well documented interface: 

https://docs.openstack.org/project-deploy-guide/tripleo-docs/latest/deployment/ansible_config_download.html

Because direct use of Ansible has been documented and supported for years removing it is a huge change. Its worth calling this out and all the use cases that might be impacted.

> 
> 
> > I was in fact talking about the what if we consider the clean room case. (Nothing I said here was to imply that we should "shove" or "blackbox" TripleO onto k8s as you assert). What is being proposed here is a significant effort though. And as such we might consider where things might end up years down the road and benefits of a world with more modern deployment tooling. There have been many efforts in this territory in the past years some internal to Red Hat, and others in the OpenStack community that might be worthy of consideration. And like above there could still be a sort of upgrade path for existing users into these modern architectures. Might have to wiggle with a few of the first principles a bit but I think the general sentiment could be achieved. 
> 
> I question why this continues to be considered a significant effort. It's probably less effort than the initial containerization or config-download (which didn't have a spec btw).  In fact this spec has vastly more detail and scale information than the initial container-tripleo-overcloud[0] spec so I continue to have trouble understanding the continued push back on this effort.  This effort is to take the existing functionality of the overall deployment framework and confine the functionality we need to projects or code bases designed for the required action rather than leveraging projects that don't focus solely on these functions (heat/ansible).  Our goal is for this to not be invasive and people continue to claim it will be.  

The implementation of containerization and config-download took multiple releases to fully support in TripleO. The level of detail or lack of a spec likely didn't impact that as much as the shear amount of work involved. At the end of the day I don't care as much what goes into this spec. But it sounds to me like we are talking about a significant chunk of work here. Understood your goal is to minimize the invasive nature of this work but as discussed above removing Ansible is by nature going to be invasive at this point. And my line of thought was more in the "if you are breaking things anyway may as well consider changing <the world>" kind of thinking. It sounds like you really want to keep Heat as a user interface and that is a valid stance.

> 
> Our existing tooling is insufficient and this is our proposal to address the upcoming issues due to tooling changes and scale related problems.  If you think there's another set of tools we should use or have thoughts about that, please provide that information rather than requesting us to go do that investigation. We did investigations and initial PoCs to address pain points that we currently hit (e.g. limited task ordering, excessive time to execute work, poor execution status) with the tooling we use today for the required actions we do as part of the deployment of containerized services on baremetal hosts.  We feel this is a limited solution without breaking the world or scraping tripleo in it's entirety.  If you think there's another solution, feel free to file a different spec as an alternative or provide levels of details similar to what is being referenced here. 

I'm not requesting you do any investigation unless you want to. There are some interesting ideas being proposed in this spec worth exploring. As I said before if I was doing it myself I might clean-room it first. A fully working POC speaks miles. I would also think very carefully about other platforms that might help solve some of these issues (and yes I do think k8s could help with some of them). Agree this could come in a different spec or entirely different clean-room effort though so we can punt on that idea as far as this spec goes I think.

> 
> [0] https://specs.openstack.org/openstack/tripleo-specs/specs/ocata/containerize-tripleo-overcloud.html'}, {'account_id': 7353, 'date': '2021-08-11 20:36:31.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5:

> I was in fact talking about the what if we consider the clean room case. (Nothing I said here was to imply that we should "shove" or "blackbox" TripleO onto k8s as you assert). What is being proposed here is a significant effort though. And as such we might consider where things might end up years down the road and benefits of a world with more modern deployment tooling. There have been many efforts in this territory in the past years some internal to Red Hat, and others in the OpenStack community that might be worthy of consideration. And like above there could still be a sort of upgrade path for existing users into these modern architectures. Might have to wiggle with a few of the first principles a bit but I think the general sentiment could be achieved. 

From the conversation context and the question, the assertion in that question was if we had considered a TripleO installer using K8S, hence the "blackbox" and "shoving" aspect of my reply; knowing that the question was about a clean-room installation of OpenStack outside of TripleO, I now understand. As mentioned, I believe it makes sense to see how far we could get with OpenStack on K8S without the TripleO legacy holding those efforts back. However, I still affirm that K8S is not relevant here. This specification leaves the deployment architecture intact, whereas changing the application runtime and installation method would profoundly impact the current architecture. All that said, if this is something being considered, it would be great to see that effort contained within a new specification.'}, {'account_id': 14985, 'date': '2021-08-11 20:41:01.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5:

> But config-download is now a well documented interface: 
> 
> https://docs.openstack.org/project-deploy-guide/tripleo-docs/latest/deployment/ansible_config_download.html
> 
> Because direct use of Ansible has been documented and supported for years removing it is a huge change. Its worth calling this out and all the use cases that might be impacted.

Yup and the changes to ansible are going to break this interface even if we do nothing because we'll have to create an execution environment for this to work. Basically we're being forced to either rewrite this thing to work with future versions of ansible or drop the manual ansible execution going forward and possibly provide a better experience and something that works at scale.


> 
> The implementation of containerization and config-download took multiple releases to fully support in TripleO. The level of detail or lack of a spec likely didn't impact that as much as the shear amount of work involved. At the end of the day I don't care as much what goes into this spec. But it sounds to me like we are talking about a significant chunk of work here. Understood your goal is to minimize the invasive nature of this work but as discussed above removing Ansible is by nature going to be invasive at this point. And my line of thought was more in the "if you are breaking things anyway may as well consider changing <the world>" kind of thinking. It sounds like you really want to keep Heat as a user interface and that is a valid stance.

Maybe we should have taken the time to actually truly investigate the performance at scale. Because clearly what we had in the spec was way off the mark.

https://opendev.org/openstack/tripleo-specs/src/branch/master/specs/ocata/containerize-tripleo-overcloud.rst#performance-impact

We don't want to necessarily remove ansible as it has it's place. But it doesn't seem to have a future in the internals of the tripleo deployment framework due to scale asks and changes in how ansible works in future versions.  We're trying to get ahead of the problem and be proactive rather than dealing with the known future breaking changes.

https://groups.google.com/g/ansible-devel/c/EPhHPTUTEDQ

Hmmm. It seems like we keep confusing two separate topics in the discussion of this spec:

1) exploration of an alternative for Ansible
2) deployment performance improvements for TripleO

And to your point above I'm not convinced containerizing the Overcloud had much of anything to do with either of these topics. We are in fact are going to keep things containerized in any architecture we choose at this point so I might suggest we put the past on this topic aside. Let it rest.

How much Ansible is going to be removed as part of this spec? All of it? Or just some of it? And are we removing that due to performance issues that we are now only just discovering or is it because of some future breaking changes in the Ansible tools themselves?

> 
> We don't want to necessarily remove ansible as it has it's place. But it doesn't seem to have a future in the internals of the tripleo deployment framework due to scale asks and changes in how ansible works in future versions.  We're trying to get ahead of the problem and be proactive rather than dealing with the known future breaking changes.
> 
> https://groups.google.com/g/ansible-devel/c/EPhHPTUTEDQ
> https://www.ansible.com/blog/introduction-to-ansible-builder

So Ansible is making some changes. Couldn't we overcome some of those if we wanted to? What are other projects planning on doing that use Ansible heavily? Kolla Ansible, Infra, etc. Is the world ending because Ansible is introducing a more containerized workflow? Is everyone going to develop their own tooling to do what Ansible has done in the past?

I do think it's worth clarifying which Ansible pieces are getting removed, and which are getting kept as part of this spec. It all goes towards level of work and how the user interfaces will be impacted.'}, {'account_id': 7144, 'date': '2021-08-12 13:02:38.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5:

I'll summarize where I'm at with this.

The scope of the spec, specifically the problem description is overly broad. I could deep dive with comments on that if there is desire, but it will feel like nitpicking.

At a high level though, the problem description describes problems with Ansible and Puppet. Maintenance, performance, scale, and complexity seem to be what is pointed out. However, the offered solutions do not fully solve the problem statement given it's broad-ness.

The scale test completed does solve for how the issue of Ansible scaling is addressed with directord. Eventually, I'd like to see more testing done here (how about 1,000 nodes with 8 tasks, or 1,000 nodes with 1,000 tasks...I'd be  curious how qdrouterd handles lots of nodes, instead of tasks), but that is not needed in the spec. I buy that it's an overall improvement over Ansible either way, and that we also have the future ability to improve.

There is language throughout the spec about moving away from Ansible, but I don't think that is made clear enough, and fully explored or explained "how". The t-h-t patch shows integration between task-core/Heat/config-download, but still uses ansible.

The task-core keystone example deploys keystone with some shell commands like devstack might.

It's not connected end to end for me, but I've *assumed* the idea is to rewrite all Ansible tasks/roles/playbooks that are used by config-download into directord orchestrations. The language "Port Ansible roles into Directord orchestration" leaves a lot to the imagination. It's actually writing new directord orchestrations from scratch that replace the ansible roles right? Into either RUN/POD or one of the other components from https://directord.com/components.html#built-in-components. The ansible roles (at least the ones specific to config-download playbooks), are deprecated when the spec is implemented (?).

The spec also does not describe how the Ansible problems are solved for other uses of Ansible throughout TripleO though, raising a lot of questions about how the spec's problem statement gets addressed (e.g., we're still maintaining Ansible).

There are no solutions in the spec about solving the described problems with Puppet. It should be removed from the spec completely, or add a new "non-work items / out of scope" section to call things out.

I think a more limited scope might be "replace Ansible as used in config-download with directord/task-core".

That is why the idea of a POC was brough up that would show "this is what we intend to do".

A POC wouldn't really be any different than if we just continued with the started implementation anyway, as if the spec were approved. And even if the spec is approved, it's not like we're locked to it anyway. So, I see no harm with proceeding with a POC/implementation, it's the same work path anyway.'}, {'account_id': 7353, 'date': '2021-08-12 13:23:30.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5:

> Patch Set 5:

> I'll summarize where I'm at with this.
>

+1 I agree some of the language in this spec is intentionally vague in an effort to not be overly inflammatory or divulge too much in terms of what may be going on with future Ansible directions. This was a risk with the spec and why it was iterated on internally before being publicly released, many of the concepts in the spec have corresponding research components that are not necessarily for public consumption. This is my fault and I will look to increase detail in certain areas and reduce scope in others.

> The scale test completed does solve for how the issue of Ansible scaling is addressed with directord. Eventually, I'd like to see more testing done here (how about 1,000 nodes with 8 tasks, or 1,000 nodes with 1,000 tasks...I'd be  curious how qdrouterd handles lots of nodes, instead of tasks), but that is not needed in the spec. The language "Port Ansible roles into Directord orchestration" leaves a lot to the imagination. It's actually writing new directord orchestrations from scratch that replace the ansible roles right? Into either RUN/POD or one of the other components from https://directord.com/components.html#built-in-components. +1 this was an over simplification on my part, I'll revise.

> I think a more limited scope might be "replace Ansible as used in config-download with directord/task-core".

+1 I'll circle up with some folks and see what we can come up with for a more robust POC.'}, {'account_id': 7353, 'date': '2021-08-12 13:24:32.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5:

Basically we're being forced to either rewrite this thing to work with future versions of ansible or drop the manual ansible execution going forward and possibly provide a better experience and something that works at scale.
> >

The level of detail or lack of a spec likely didn't impact that as much as the shear amount of work involved. At the end of the day I don't care as much what goes into this spec. But it sounds to me like we are talking about a significant chunk of work here. Understood your goal is to minimize the invasive nature of this work but as discussed above removing Ansible is by nature going to be invasive at this point. And my line of thought was more in the "if you are breaking things anyway may as well consider changing <the world>" kind of thinking. It sounds like you really want to keep Heat as a user interface and that is a valid stance.
> > 
> > Maybe we should have taken the time to actually truly investigate the performance at scale. Because clearly what we had in the spec was way off the mark.
> > 
> > https://opendev.org/openstack/tripleo-specs/src/branch/master/specs/ocata/containerize-tripleo-overcloud.rst#performance-impact
> 
> Hmmm. It seems like we keep confusing two separate topics in the discussion of this spec:
> 
> 1) exploration of an alternative for Ansible
> 2) deployment performance improvements for TripleO
> 
> And to your point above I'm not convinced containerizing the Overcloud had much of anything to do with either of these topics. We are in fact are going to keep things containerized in any architecture we choose at this point so I might suggest we put the past on this topic aside. Let it rest.
> 
> How much Ansible is going to be removed as part of this spec? All of it? Or just some of it? And are we removing that due to performance issues that we are now only just discovering or is it because of some future breaking changes in the Ansible tools themselves?

In terms of TripleO deployment we're scoping the replacement of all of Ansible roles and tasks. In terms of Ansible having it's place, it makes sense to keep tooling that better enable operators to do administrative tasks. That said, the base command line utilities will cease to exist. While that isn't fully spelled out from an Ansible community point of view, downstream we have no future options with the tools we know and use today.

We've been privy to the Ansible performance issues for a while, and have done quite a bit of work to try and over come some of them. Downstream we have quite a few examples of these issues and what has been done to address them. To summarize, most of the solutions to Ansible scale issues have been to do less, in batches. 

> > 
> > We don't want to necessarily remove ansible as it has it's place. But it doesn't seem to have a future in the internals of the tripleo deployment framework due to scale asks and changes in how ansible works in future versions.  We're trying to get ahead of the problem and be proactive rather than dealing with the known future breaking changes.
> > 
> > https://groups.google.com/g/ansible-devel/c/EPhHPTUTEDQ
> > https://www.ansible.com/blog/introduction-to-ansible-builder
> 
> So Ansible is making some changes. Couldn't we overcome some of those if we wanted to? What are other projects planning on doing that use Ansible heavily? Kolla Ansible, Infra, etc. Is the world ending because Ansible is introducing a more containerized workflow? Is everyone going to develop their own tooling to do what Ansible has done in the past?

I'm not sure what other projects are doing, while I know projects like OpenStack-Ansible shouldn't be impacted given they build everything from source (Kolla has a source based solution too), other projects will need to figure out what future path makes sense to them. We do have a technical means to overcome the issues and have POC'd that work [0]; however, after carful analysis of that effort it was determined to be a non-starter (this is where we found, and reported, more performance and user-experience problems). 

> I do think it's worth clarifying which Ansible pieces are getting removed, and which are getting kept as part of this spec. It all goes towards level of work and how the user interfaces will be impacted.

+1 I agree. I will look to improve that level of detail either in this specification or in supporting documentation.

> Patch Set 5:
> 
> Tbh, I'm slightly concerned that this keeps ignoring Kubernetes as the future base platform for OpenStack. That may be fine, as of today. Or may be not at all, as of future fast-forward-upgrades perspective. I can envision we'll return to that topic one day, and there might be some *better* K8s native options for continuous delivery of openstack as an app than the suggested directord approach.

I keep seeing this reference that Kubernetes is the future of OpenStack, but I don't understand where that came from. Has that been discussed among the community and confirmed, or is this an internal direction assumption? I also don't know what using Kubernetes as the base platform might look like.

There is a Director Operator that leverages virtual machines for the control plane and then (my understanding) is that the computes and such remain baremetal for workload handling. Is that what you're referring to here?

Anything to help speed up and the deployment of an OpenStack system would be welcome news, and I'm not sure I see a conflict between this and Director Operator. To me this spec seems like a welcome interim solution that could be leveraged by either a traditional installation method _and_ by something like Director Operator that would ideally speed up a deployment, making iterating on OpenStack soooooo much more palatable.

A full k8s-native solution to deploying OpenStack always feels weird to me. Are we talking about turning every service in to an Operator and then building a new method to hook all those services up and re-build the existing logic back in to that? Or is taking an installation tool that has better awareness that it might live on top of k8s as a deployment-infrastructure and expose configurations that are friendlier to the k8s approach to using manifests and objects via Custom Resources? Or should the work be to build in enough knowledge _IN_ to k8s to allow "OpenStack native workloads" to be scheduled on particular aggregates and not even really have an "installer" but rather just enough k8s-controllers that workloads that still need OpenStack are able to be scheduled against baremetal nodes that are provisioned in a particular way?

I guess my point is that an iterative approach, or perhaps a forked approach where two separate methods are co-developed might make sense here. Using something like directord+task-core (or whatever) where existing templating and business logic can simply be dropped in and re-used while providing a significant bump to an administrators experience, while building what I suspect will be a much longer process to determining what a k8s-native approach would look like, and then built along with the documentation, CI, release tooling, and all the other overhead aspects that come along with net-new projects.

Alternatively, as pointed out early in this spec, effectively abandon TripleO by placing it in to a maintenance contract where the work will simply be to maintain ability to deploy OpenStack artifacts without any expectation of an appreciable gain in administrator experience with a focus on building new tooling that allows OpenStack workloads to co-exist in a k8s environment.'}, {'account_id': 14985, 'date': '2021-08-16 13:58:01.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 5:

> Patch Set 5: Code-Review-1
> 
> I wouldn't invest in directord, but rather a k8s deployment solution instead

No thanks.  That would be best solved not trying to make tripleo know how to deploy k8s too.  There's nothing stopping us from adopting k8s as a place to deploy (similar to baremetal).  I disagree with the push for k8s and while I can appreciate some folks desire to have that as a deployment target, that's a different conversation and I have yet to see how k8s solves anything that is raised in this spec in terms of scalability, flexibility, etc."}, {'account_id': 6926, 'date': '2021-08-17 08:33:22.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5:

> I keep seeing this reference that Kubernetes is the future of OpenStack, but I don't understand where that came from. Has that been discussed among the community and confirmed, or is this an internal direction assumption? I also don't know what using Kubernetes as the base platform might look like.

Assuming it might become the future platform already questions the feasibility of interim solutions like this one. FFU development, backporting things to branches that have already near to zero common architecture (because of interim solutions we add or change each release) becomes hard - to maintain and to move forward. We have a ~3 years lag for the committed architecture changes to hit production via downstream releases. And even longer, if adding FFU feedback loops. Let's just please hold piling up more of interim solutions and stabilize. As a stabilization I understand establishing long running feedback loops from production deployments (including FFU) and bringing it back as improvements and regressions fixed for the current upstream architecture of TripleO. Then perhaps we'll be ready for such drastic changes, either with Directord, or k8s native orchestration.

> 
> There is a Director Operator that leverages virtual machines for the control plane and then (my understanding) is that the computes and such remain baremetal for workload handling. Is that what you're referring to here?

Not at this early phases, but probably that might be a thing, eventually.

> 
> Anything to help speed up and the deployment of an OpenStack system would be welcome news, and I'm not sure I see a conflict between this and Director Operator. To me this spec seems like a welcome interim solution that could be leveraged by either a traditional installation method _and_ by something like Director Operator that would ideally speed up a deployment, making iterating on OpenStack soooooo much more palatable.
> 
> A full k8s-native solution to deploying OpenStack always feels weird to me. Are we talking about turning every service in to an Operator and then building a new method to hook all those services up and re-build the existing logic back in to that? Or is taking an installation tool that has better awareness that it might live on top of k8s as a deployment-infrastructure and expose configurations that are friendlier to the k8s approach to using manifests and objects via Custom Resources? Or should the work be to build in enough knowledge _IN_ to k8s to allow "OpenStack native workloads" to be scheduled on particular aggregates and not even really have an "installer" but rather just enough k8s-controllers that workloads that still need OpenStack are able to be scheduled against baremetal nodes that are provisioned in a particular way?

K8s native would likely use CRs, and operators, yes. But I also really hope that it *will* leverage its container-native CD (Tekton) and GitOps (ArgoCD) projects to build and deploy OpenStack as a CN app. And that will replace whatever we have developed for TripleO for graphs building and tasks execution here... There is more tooling for k8s multi-cluster (and multi-region OpenStack apps on top of it) as well. Chasing these targets also interim for tripleo looks pointless, and ignoring such a great tech - not architectural wise.

> 
> I guess my point is that an iterative approach, or perhaps a forked approach where two separate methods are co-developed might make sense here. Using something like directord+task-core (or whatever)

As I noted above, that brings too much development and maintenance overhead and generates the stabilization dept.

 where existing templating and business logic can simply be dropped in and re-used while providing a significant bump to an administrators experience, while building what I suspect will be a much longer process to determining what a k8s-native approach would look like, and then built along with the documentation, CI, release tooling, and all the other overhead aspects that come along with net-new projects.
> 
> Alternatively, as pointed out early in this spec, effectively abandon TripleO by placing it in to a maintenance contract where the work will simply be to maintain ability to deploy OpenStack artifacts without any expectation of an appreciable gain in administrator experience with a focus on building new tooling that allows OpenStack workloads to co-exist in a k8s environment.'}, {'account_id': 6926, 'date': '2021-08-17 08:42:28.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 5:

> Patch Set 5:
> 
> > Patch Set 5: Code-Review-1
> > 
> > I wouldn't invest in directord, but rather a k8s deployment solution instead
> 
> No thanks.  That would be best solved not trying to make tripleo know how to deploy k8s too.  There's nothing stopping us from adopting k8s as a place to deploy (similar to baremetal).  I disagree with the push for k8s and while I can appreciate some folks desire to have that as a deployment target, that's a different conversation and I have yet to see how k8s solves anything that is raised in this spec in terms of scalability, flexibility, etc.

K8s is not only a place to where tripleo could deploy, like baremetal. It's an ecosystem of tooling to build and deploy by its own means and channels. And I don't see the need to make tripleo aware of how to deploy k8s, but only take it as an input, like the deployed-servers case."}, {'account_id': 7353, 'date': '2021-09-09 21:25:37.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5:

(11 comments)'}, {'account_id': 7144, 'date': '2021-09-14 14:15:45.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5: Code-Review-1

Add spec to introduce task-core and directord into the tripleo stack.

commit_message:
Allow to add reviewers for DPL teams

These teams are PTL-less and not necessary define their
release liaison openstack/release/data/release_liaison.yaml.

The problem is that their official reviewers arn't necessarly
detected.

These changes allow to consider these release liaisons folks.

Change-Id: I29295dddb2619043a43957e5e2c2f64d0787784b

subject: Fix UEFI record regex
messages: [{'account_id': 11655, 'date': '2021-11-08 14:05:34.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 23851, 'date': '2021-11-08 14:07:01.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2 Workflow+1'}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2021-11-08 14:05:34.000000000', 'message': 'Fix UEFI record regex

I accidently put colons on the test data and remembered taking the
colon character out of the regex I was working on, but apparently
left it in, and accounted for the active entry indicator flag
which appears to have inconsistent support across vendors.

The regex has been fixed, and a test added from a Lenovo SR650
which has some additional string entry data in the UEFI output
which may separate entries.

Change-Id: I1f67b0fb1f645fa82e98bd7c7bba3ffc7755cc74
'}]
commit_message:
Fix UEFI record regex

I accidently put colons on the test data and remembered taking the
colon character out of the regex I was working on, but apparently
left it in, and accounted for the active entry indicator flag
which appears to have inconsistent support across vendors.

The regex has been fixed, and a test added from a Lenovo SR650
which has some additional string entry data in the UEFI output
which may separate entries.

Change-Id: I1f67b0fb1f645fa82e98bd7c7bba3ffc7755cc74

commit_message:
Allow to check release approval for DPL teams

These teams are PTL-less and not necessary define their
release liaison in openstack/release/data/release_liaison.yaml.

The problem is that their release liaison approval is not
necessarily detected.

These changes allow to consider these release liaisons folks.

Furthermore, patch Id0d6eeaf66394806374781d1cf26c087a6e90f87,
from the similar script in project-config repository, also applied
here in this script to avoid exception in case of DPL teams.

Change-Id: Ieaf1eafc6a8e3ce443d73876e525f738e51dea67

commit_message:

Add some VirtualMedia fields from 1.3.0 and 1.4.0

Adds and allows changing TransferMethod and VerifyCertificate.
Also allows reading UserName.

commit_message:
Remove update converge

Update converge is largely unnecessary now with
ephemeral Heat. There is no Heat stack to update,
so we are doing nothing more than executing a
standard deployment using Ansible. Removing
the requirement for update converge will simplify
the process and improve user experience by reducing
the time it takes to perform minor updates.

Related: https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/python-tripleoclient/+/810132
Change-Id: I6ea4d91165644d28a575dfebeada588f7a8cd7f3

With a jetpack!'}, {'_account_id': 22348, 'name': 'Zuul', 'username': 'zuul', 'tags': ['SERVICE_USER']}, {'_account_id': 23851, 'name': 'Riccardo Pittau', 'email': 'elfosardo@gmail.com', 'username': 'elfosardo'}]
messages: [{'account_id': 23851, 'date': '2021-11-04 08:22:48.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Cherry Picked from branch master.'}, {'account_id': 23851, 'date': '2021-11-08 14:07:52.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2 Workflow+1'}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2021-11-04 08:22:48.000000000', 'message': 'Delete EFI boot entry duplicate labels first

Some firmware seems to take an objection with EFI nvram
entries being deleted after one is added, resulting in the
entire entry table being reset to the last known good state.

This is problematic, as ultimately deployments can time out
if we previously booted with Networking, and the machine, while
commanded to do other wise, reboots back to networking regardless.

We will now delete entries first, before proceeding.

Additionally, for general use, this pattern may serve the
community better by avoiding cases where we would have
previously just relied upon efibootmgr[0] to warn us of duplicate
entries.

[0]: https://github.com/rhboot/efibootmgr/blob/103aa22ece98f09fe3ea2a0c83988f0ee2d0e5a8/src/efibootmgr.c#L228

Change-Id: Ib61a7100a059e79a8b0901fd8f46b9bc41d657dc
Story: 2009649
Task: 43808
(cherry picked from commit 67eddfa7e3fedbb530045f5b43a2c89db832fa2a)
'}]
commit_message:
Delete EFI boot entry duplicate labels first

Some firmware seems to take an objection with EFI nvram
entries being deleted after one is added, resulting in the
entire entry table being reset to the last known good state.

This is problematic, as ultimately deployments can time out
if we previously booted with Networking, and the machine, while
commanded to do other wise, reboots back to networking regardless.

We will now delete entries first, before proceeding.

Additionally, for general use, this pattern may serve the
community better by avoiding cases where we would have
previously just relied upon efibootmgr[0] to warn us of duplicate
entries.

[0]: https://github.com/rhboot/efibootmgr/blob/103aa22ece98f09fe3ea2a0c83988f0ee2d0e5a8/src/efibootmgr.c#L228

Change-Id: Ib61a7100a059e79a8b0901fd8f46b9bc41d657dc
Story: 2009649
Task: 43808
(cherry picked from commit 67eddfa7e3fedbb530045f5b43a2c89db832fa2a)

revisions:
[{'created': '2021-11-08 11:20:09.000000000', 'message': 'Fix instance action event result inconsistent

    The instance action events will record all events in
    wrap_instance_event. The event result is inconsistent
    when execute the repeated event.
    We should update the latest event in action_event_finish.

Closes-bug: #1950138
Change-Id: Ib18ff53a5fa312cd7a157d116caabd8ee48bd204
'}]
commit_message:
Fix instance action event result inconsistent

    The instance action events will record all events in
    wrap_instance_event. The event result is inconsistent
    when execute the repeated event.
    We should update the latest event in action_event_finish.

Closes-bug: #1950138
Change-Id: Ib18ff53a5fa312cd7a157d116caabd8ee48bd204

in TripleO. Describe available options if one is have to be used.

Signed-off-by: Bogdan Dobrelya <bdobreli@redhat.com>

Document DeployedServerPortMap deprecation

Adds documentation around the deprecation of DeployedServerPortMap and
also updates the deployed-server docs to remove the parts related to
configuring the nodes with Heat as that has not been used since Queens.

if we decide not to reviert this we should do https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/nova/+/804292 instead.'}, {'account_id': 26515, 'date': '2021-08-11 20:37:15.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

(1 comment)

OK, I think we need to think more about the pinning. The original change removes the way to select which python version the targets like pep8, fast8, lower-constraints runs.'}, {'account_id': 15334, 'date': '2021-08-20 10:51:25.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

Can we compromise here and keep the '[lower-constraints] basepython' but drop the '[testenv] basepython'? That would be good enough for me. Most of our upper constraints work on Python 3.9 now but this isn't the case for the lower constraints.

Another alternative is to bump the lower-constraints to work with Python 3.9, but we don't technically support that yet so it's a bit weird (and a lot of work).

The last option is to merge this as-is, but like I said it means anyone on Fedora can't run lower constraints without adding versioned variants of everything, which I don't want to do (I'd rather just hack in basepython every time I need to run it) :-("}, {'account_id': 11604, 'date': '2021-08-20 11:20:19.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

> Patch Set 2:
> 
> Can we compromise here and keep the '[lower-constraints] basepython' but drop the '[testenv] basepython'? That would be good enough for me. Most of our upper constraints work on Python 3.9 now but this isn't the case for the lower constraints.
> 
> Another alternative is to bump the lower-constraints to work with Python 3.9, but we don't technically support that yet so it's a bit weird (and a lot of work).
> 
> The last option is to merge this as-is, but like I said it means anyone on Fedora can't run lower constraints without adding versioned variants of everything, which I don't want to do (I'd rather just hack in basepython every time I need to run it) :-(

im more ok with defaulting to 3.6 or 3.8 if we can also override it 

so if we were to use the genertiave tox endpoint then i would be ok with default to 3.6 for lower constratins since we can just override that wehn we run it by appending the python verison we want."}, {'account_id': 9708, 'date': '2021-08-23 11:47:56.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

> Patch Set 2:
> 
> Can we compromise here and keep the '[lower-constraints] basepython' but drop the '[testenv] basepython'? That would be good enough for me. Most of our upper constraints work on Python 3.9 now but this isn't the case for the lower constraints.
> 
> Another alternative is to bump the lower-constraints to work with Python 3.9, but we don't technically support that yet so it's a bit weird (and a lot of work).
> 
> The last option is to merge this as-is, but like I said it means anyone on Fedora can't run lower constraints without adding versioned variants of everything, which I don't want to do (I'd rather just hack in basepython every time I need to run it) :-(

I'm OK to compromise on lower-constraints being pinned and the rest isn't"}, {'account_id': 8556, 'date': '2021-10-20 13:20:05.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Code-Review+2
